title: How to Make Turkey Pot Pie

steps.headline: Whisk the flour with salt and sugar.
steps.description: Put 3 cups (375 g) of all-purpose flour into a large mixing bowl and add 1 teaspoon (6 g) of kosher salt along with 1 tablespoon (12 g) of granulated sugar. Whisk the dry ingredients for 30 seconds so they're combined. If you prefer, sift the flour with the salt and sugar instead of using a whisk.

steps.headline: Cut in the butter and shortening.
steps.description: Add 12 tablespoons (1668 g) of diced butter and 1/3 cup (67 g) of vegetable shortening. Use your fingers, forks, or a pastry cutter to push the fats into the flour. Keep mixing and smashing until the fats are the size of peas.Variation: You can make the dough in a food processor. Put all of the ingredients into the processor and pulse the mixture 8 to 12 times. Keep the butter and shortening as cold as possible so the heat from your fingers doesn't melt them. This will help the pastry become flaky.

steps.headline: Mix in up to ⁄2 cup (120 ml) of ice water.
steps.description: Pour about 1/2 of the ice water into the bowl and use a fork to stir the mixture until a shaggy dough forms. You should see the flour begin to clump together as it becomes moist. If the mixture looks too dry to hold together, stir in the remaining ⁄4 cup (59 ml) of ice water a few spoonfuls at a time. If you're making the dough in a food processor, keep the machine running and pour 1/2 of the water into the feed tube. Then mix in the rest of the water as needed.

steps.headline: Wrap the dough in plastic wrap and chill it for 30 minutes.
steps.description: Sprinkle a little flour on your work surface and turn the dough onto it. Form the dough into a ball and wrap it tightly in plastic wrap. Put the dough in the refrigerator and let it rest for 30 minutes. Chilling the dough will relax the gluten so the pastry is tender and not tough.

parts.name: Cooking the Turkey and Vegetable Filling

steps.headline: Dice the onion, carrot, and celery into ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) pieces.
steps.description: Peel 1 onion and 1 carrot. You'll also need to trim the ends from 1 stalk of celery. Use a knife to dice the vegetables into even pieces that are all ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) in size. To save time, you might be able to buy onion, carrot, and celery that are already finely diced.

steps.headline: Sauté the diced vegetables for 7 minutes over medium heat.
steps.description: Put 3 tablespoons (42 g) of butter into a saucepan and turn the burner on to medium. Once the butter melts, stir in the diced onion, carrot, and celery. Cook the vegetables until they soften a little. This should take around 7 minutes. Stir the vegetables occasionally to prevent them from sticking to the bottom of the saucepan.

steps.headline: Stir in flour and cook the vegetables for 1 minute.
steps.description: Sprinkle 3 tablespoons (23 g) of flour over the sautéing vegetables in the saucepan. Stir until the vegetables are coated with the flour and keep cooking them for 1 minute. The flour will thicken the filling for the turkey pot pie.

steps.headline: Add the broth, milk, and cream.
steps.description: Slowly pour in 2 ⁄2 cups (590 ml) of turkey or chicken broth, ⁄2 cup (120 ml) of milk, and ⁄2 cup (120 ml) of heavy cream or leftover gravy.Tip: For the richest tasting pot pie, use whole milk instead of skim or low-fat milk.

steps.headline: Stir the filling mixture and bring it to a simmer.
steps.description: Keep the burner turned to medium and stir the filling frequently. It should begin to bubble gently and thicken as some of the liquid evaporates. You can also stir in 1/4 teaspoon (0.5 g) of ground black pepper. Taste the filling and add salt according to your taste.

steps.headline: Add 1/2 of a large potato to the saucepan.
steps.description: Take the potato 1/2 and use a sharp knife to carefully dice it into ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) pieces. Stir the potato into the saucepan with the filling mixture. The diced potato should be covered by the liquid in the saucepan.

steps.headline: Cover the saucepan and simmer the mixture for 12 minutes.
steps.description: Put the lid on the saucepan and keep the burner at medium heat. The liquid should bubble gently so the potatoes cook. Simmer the filling until the potatoes are tender. To test if the potatoes are tender, stick a fork into a piece of potato. If you can slide the fork in and out easily, the potatoes are done. If you can't, cook them for another 2 minutes and check again.

steps.headline: Turn off the heat and stir in the peas, turkey, and herbs.
steps.description: Remove the lid and turn off the burner. Then stir in 1/2 cup (75 g) of frozen peas, 2 cups (250 g) of shredded or chopped cooked turkey, 1 tablespoon (4 g) of minced parsley, and 1 tablespoon (4 g) of your choice of herb, such as sage, rosemary, thyme. There's no need to heat or defrost the frozen peas before you add them to the filling mixture. The heat from the mixture will warm the peas.

parts.name: Assembling and Baking the Pot Pie

steps.headline: Preheat the oven to 375 °F (191 °C) and get out the dough.
steps.description: Take the chilled ball of pastry dough out of the refrigerator and unwrap it. Set the dough on a floured surface so you can begin to roll it out.Tip: To save time, use storebought pastry dough that you simply lay in the deep-dish pie plate.

steps.headline: Divide the dough in 1/2 and roll each piece into a 12 in (30 cm) circle.
steps.description: Use a knife to cut the dough in 1/2 and set 1 piece aside. Then use a rolling pin to roll out the first circle on your floured surface. Keep turning the dough to prevent it from sticking as you roll it into an even circle. You might want to flour your rolling pin occasionally if the dough sticks to the pin.

steps.headline: Line a pie plate with the pastry and roll out the remaining dough.
steps.description: Get out a 9 in × 2 in (22.9 cm × 5.1 cm) deep-dish pie plate and carefully lay the rolled out circle of pastry dough in the bottom of the dish. The dough should come up and over the sides of the plate. Then roll the other piece of dough into another 12 in (30 cm) circle. If you don't have a deep-dish pie plate, use a 2 US qt (1.9 L) baking dish instead. Avoid using a shallow pie plate because the filling will overflow.

steps.headline: Spread the turkey filling in the pie plate.
steps.description: Spoon the slightly cooled turkey filling into the pastry-lined pie plate. Use the back of a spoon to level the filling so the top layer of pastry will sit evenly on the filling.

steps.headline: Lay the remaining pastry over the filling and pinch the edges to seal them.
steps.description: Carefully arrange the remaining circle of pastry dough over the filling in the pie plate. Then use your fingers to pinch the bottom layer of pastry with the top layer. Do this around the entire pie plate so the pastry is sealed. Pinching the edges will prevent the pastry from leaking out as the pot pie bakes.

steps.headline: Cut 2 slits on the top of the pie and brush it with an egg wash. Take a sharp knife and cut 2 slits about 2 inches (5.1 cm) long through the top layer of pastry.
steps.description: This will allow steam to escape as the pie bakes. Then beat 1 egg with 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of water and brush the wash over the top of the pie. The egg wash will make the pot pie become golden brown as it bakes. If you don't want to use an egg wash, brush the pastry with whole milk or heavy cream instead.

steps.headline: Bake the turkey pot pie for 35 minutes.
steps.description: Put the assembled turkey pot pie in the preheated oven and bake it until the crust becomes a rich brown color. You should see steam escaping from the slits you cut. If you're worried that the filling may bubble up and over the side of the pie plate, lay a sheet of aluminum foil or a baking sheet on the rack underneath the pie.

steps.headline: Serve the turkey pot pie with a green salad.
steps.description: Turn off the oven and carefully remove the hot pot pie. Although you can cut and serve it immediately, it may be easier to serve if you wait a few minutes so the filling sets up a little. Consider serving the pot pie with a fresh green salad. Refrigerate the leftover pot pie for up to 3 to 4 days in an airtight container.

text: Making the Pie Crust Whisk the flour with salt and sugar. Put 3 cups (375 g) of all-purpose flour into a large mixing bowl and add 1 teaspoon (6 g) of kosher salt along with 1 tablespoon (12 g) of granulated sugar. Whisk the dry ingredients for 30 seconds so they're combined. If you prefer, sift the flour with the salt and sugar instead of using a whisk. Cut in the butter and shortening. Add 12 tablespoons (1668 g) of diced butter and 1/3 cup (67 g) of vegetable shortening. Use your fingers, forks, or a pastry cutter to push the fats into the flour. Keep mixing and smashing until the fats are the size of peas.Variation: You can make the dough in a food processor. Put all of the ingredients into the processor and pulse the mixture 8 to 12 times. Keep the butter and shortening as cold as possible so the heat from your fingers doesn't melt them. This will help the pastry become flaky. Mix in up to ⁄2 cup (120 ml) of ice water. Pour about 1/2 of the ice water into the bowl and use a fork to stir the mixture until a shaggy dough forms. You should see the flour begin to clump together as it becomes moist. If the mixture looks too dry to hold together, stir in the remaining ⁄4 cup (59 ml) of ice water a few spoonfuls at a time. If you're making the dough in a food processor, keep the machine running and pour 1/2 of the water into the feed tube. Then mix in the rest of the water as needed. Wrap the dough in plastic wrap and chill it for 30 minutes. Sprinkle a little flour on your work surface and turn the dough onto it. Form the dough into a ball and wrap it tightly in plastic wrap. Put the dough in the refrigerator and let it rest for 30 minutes. Chilling the dough will relax the gluten so the pastry is tender and not tough. Cooking the Turkey and Vegetable Filling Dice the onion, carrot, and celery into ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) pieces. Peel 1 onion and 1 carrot. You'll also need to trim the ends from 1 stalk of celery. Use a knife to dice the vegetables into even pieces that are all ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) in size. To save time, you might be able to buy onion, carrot, and celery that are already finely diced. Sauté the diced vegetables for 7 minutes over medium heat. Put 3 tablespoons (42 g) of butter into a saucepan and turn the burner on to medium. Once the butter melts, stir in the diced onion, carrot, and celery. Cook the vegetables until they soften a little. This should take around 7 minutes. Stir the vegetables occasionally to prevent them from sticking to the bottom of the saucepan. Stir in flour and cook the vegetables for 1 minute. Sprinkle 3 tablespoons (23 g) of flour over the sautéing vegetables in the saucepan. Stir until the vegetables are coated with the flour and keep cooking them for 1 minute. The flour will thicken the filling for the turkey pot pie. Add the broth, milk, and cream. Slowly pour in 2 ⁄2 cups (590 ml) of turkey or chicken broth, ⁄2 cup (120 ml) of milk, and ⁄2 cup (120 ml) of heavy cream or leftover gravy.Tip: For the richest tasting pot pie, use whole milk instead of skim or low-fat milk. Stir the filling mixture and bring it to a simmer. Keep the burner turned to medium and stir the filling frequently. It should begin to bubble gently and thicken as some of the liquid evaporates. You can also stir in 1/4 teaspoon (0.5 g) of ground black pepper. Taste the filling and add salt according to your taste. Add 1/2 of a large potato to the saucepan. Take the potato 1/2 and use a sharp knife to carefully dice it into ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) pieces. Stir the potato into the saucepan with the filling mixture. The diced potato should be covered by the liquid in the saucepan. Cover the saucepan and simmer the mixture for 12 minutes. Put the lid on the saucepan and keep the burner at medium heat. The liquid should bubble gently so the potatoes cook. Simmer the filling until the potatoes are tender. To test if the potatoes are tender, stick a fork into a piece of potato. If you can slide the fork in and out easily, the potatoes are done. If you can't, cook them for another 2 minutes and check again. Turn off the heat and stir in the peas, turkey, and herbs. Remove the lid and turn off the burner. Then stir in 1/2 cup (75 g) of frozen peas, 2 cups (250 g) of shredded or chopped cooked turkey, 1 tablespoon (4 g) of minced parsley, and 1 tablespoon (4 g) of your choice of herb, such as sage, rosemary, thyme. There's no need to heat or defrost the frozen peas before you add them to the filling mixture. The heat from the mixture will warm the peas. Assembling and Baking the Pot Pie Preheat the oven to 375 °F (191 °C) and get out the dough. Take the chilled ball of pastry dough out of the refrigerator and unwrap it. Set the dough on a floured surface so you can begin to roll it out.Tip: To save time, use storebought pastry dough that you simply lay in the deep-dish pie plate. Divide the dough in 1/2 and roll each piece into a 12 in (30 cm) circle. Use a knife to cut the dough in 1/2 and set 1 piece aside. Then use a rolling pin to roll out the first circle on your floured surface. Keep turning the dough to prevent it from sticking as you roll it into an even circle. You might want to flour your rolling pin occasionally if the dough sticks to the pin. Line a pie plate with the pastry and roll out the remaining dough. Get out a 9 in × 2 in (22.9 cm × 5.1 cm) deep-dish pie plate and carefully lay the rolled out circle of pastry dough in the bottom of the dish. The dough should come up and over the sides of the plate. Then roll the other piece of dough into another 12 in (30 cm) circle. If you don't have a deep-dish pie plate, use a 2 US qt (1.9 L) baking dish instead. Avoid using a shallow pie plate because the filling will overflow. Spread the turkey filling in the pie plate. Spoon the slightly cooled turkey filling into the pastry-lined pie plate. Use the back of a spoon to level the filling so the top layer of pastry will sit evenly on the filling. Lay the remaining pastry over the filling and pinch the edges to seal them. Carefully arrange the remaining circle of pastry dough over the filling in the pie plate. Then use your fingers to pinch the bottom layer of pastry with the top layer. Do this around the entire pie plate so the pastry is sealed. Pinching the edges will prevent the pastry from leaking out as the pot pie bakes. Cut 2 slits on the top of the pie and brush it with an egg wash. Take a sharp knife and cut 2 slits about 2 inches (5.1 cm) long through the top layer of pastry. This will allow steam to escape as the pie bakes. Then beat 1 egg with 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of water and brush the wash over the top of the pie. The egg wash will make the pot pie become golden brown as it bakes. If you don't want to use an egg wash, brush the pastry with whole milk or heavy cream instead. Bake the turkey pot pie for 35 minutes. Put the assembled turkey pot pie in the preheated oven and bake it until the crust becomes a rich brown color. You should see steam escaping from the slits you cut. If you're worried that the filling may bubble up and over the side of the pie plate, lay a sheet of aluminum foil or a baking sheet on the rack underneath the pie. Serve the turkey pot pie with a green salad. Turn off the oven and carefully remove the hot pot pie. Although you can cut and serve it immediately, it may be easier to serve if you wait a few minutes so the filling sets up a little. Consider serving the pot pie with a fresh green salad. Refrigerate the leftover pot pie for up to 3 to 4 days in an airtight container.
